channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Purdue Perl Mongers
item.description: December 11, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: Toronto Perl Mongers monthly meeting
item.description: November 28, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: Purdue Perl Mongers
item.description: November 13, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: Boston.pm monthly meeting
item.description: November 12, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: How I Spent My First London Perl Workshop
item.description: A very colorful presentation, I must admit. Glad that you had great time in London.

item.title: Smashed TVs, Broken Windows, and Cracked Plates
item.description: Hear from the organiser of LPW what it takes to origanise an event. Kudos for all thier efforts.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report.

item.title: Permutationally Consecutive
item.description: Another dose of Raku gems discussed and it is not to be missed. Highly recommended.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #294
item.description: Thanks for sharing the research of finding the lexicographically next permutation. Plenty to learn from this week work.

item.title: Sequential permutations
item.description: A detailed proof of O(n) time is worth checking. Kudos for the effort, thanks for sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: No music, only numbers
item.description: Anyone looking for Raku magic then this is the best place where Raku implementation is discussed in details. Having said, I missed the musical aspect.

item.title: Consecutive Sequences of Permutations, Anyone?
item.description: The detailed analysis to sort out the O(n) time is very impressive. There is always something new to learn from your contributions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 294
item.description: Compact one-liner in Perl for all with enough discussion to get to the core. Well done and keep it up.

item.title: Consecutive Permutations
item.description: A very interesting discussion about the use of data structure to get around O(n) time. It's worth checking out, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 294
item.description: Making good use of Raku built-in functions and getting job done in no time. Smart move, well done.

item.title: Next Consecutive
item.description: The verbosity of solutions is the main attraction for me, not just this week but every week. It gives away lots of inner details. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: TWC294
item.description: Rare pairing of 'unless' inside 'foreach' and we have a compact solution, very impressive. Please keep sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 294
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Consecutive Sequence" and "Next Permutation" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 295
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Word Break" and "Jump Game". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Dancer2 Documentation Grant Report
item.description: Great to see the improvement work being carried out in my favourite web framework, Dancer2.

item.title: I wish Mojo::UserAgent could be made to not visit private IPs
item.description: An interesting discussion started around the use of Mojo::UserAgent. What is your view on this?

item.title: Further on Perl Camel
item.description: The good old discussion of Perl Camel is back ...

item.title: Multiple Inheritance vs Role
item.description: A simplified comparison between Multiple Inheritance and Roles.

item.title: This week in PSC (167) | 2024-11-07
item.description: It seems very busy week, lots of topics discussed amd agreed upon. Happy to see things moving really fast. Thank you Perl Steering Council.

item.title: London Perl & Raku Workshop 2024: Recordings & Thoughts
item.description: For all who missed the LPW 2024, we now have the recordings of the event. Audio quality may not be great, I must inform you upfront.

item.title: #694 - LPW: Past, Present & Future
item.description:
Hi there,

It has been two weeks since the London Perl and Raku Workshop 2024, and we are still receiving attendee reports. Thank you to everyone who took the time to share their experiences. Last week, I came across two such reports by Lee Johnson and Olaf Alders. I'm still hoping to find a moment to reflect on my own workshop experience.

LPW holds a special place in my heart, as it was the first workshop where I gave my first talk ever. I was introduced to LPW by a colleague at work. Back then, there was always an O'Reilly stall outside the theater room, selling Perl books and surrounded by a large crowd. I remember the days when we had three strong tracks running simultaneously and, especially, the last LPW organized by Mark Keating and his team. The transition was seamless, and we continued the workshop smoothly until COVID-19 struck. For a brief period, I was part of the organizing team, but my contributions were limited to promoting the event and assisting attendees on the day.

Bringing the workshop back after COVID-19 was the brainchild of Lee Johnson and Julien Fiegehenn. Their hard work truly paid off, as the event was well-attended and praised for its smooth execution. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the organizing team for providing a platform to reconnect with friends from around the world. The future of LPW looks bright as I’m hearing a lot of positive feedback about next year’s workshop, and I'm keeping my fingers crossed.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
